data.title: Maria Nikolaevna Romanova
data.text:
my-colorful-world-is-crazy:

Grand Duchess Maria Nikolaevna Romanova of Russia, “The Angel" of the Family.

She was a wonderful girl, possessed of a tremendous reserve force, and I never realised her unselfish nature until those dreadful days. She too was exceeding fair, dowered with the classic beauty of the Romanovs: her eyes were dark blue, shaded by long lashes, and she had masses of dark brown hair. Marie was plump, and the Empress often teased her about this; she was not so lively as her sisters, but she was much more decided in her outlook. The Grand Duchess Marie knew at once what she wanted, and why she wanted it.“ - Lili Dehn

Marie Nikolaievna was like Olga Nikolaievna in colouring and features, but all on a more vivid scale. She had the same charming smile, the same shape of face, but her eyes, “Marie’s saucers,” as they were called by her cousins, were magnificent, and of a deep dark blue. Her hair had golden lights in it, and when it was cut after her illness in 1917, it curled naturally over her head.- Sophie Buxhoeveden

Grand Duchesses Maria and Anastasia with Pierre Gilliard on the lake at the Alexander Palace: 1915.

tragicrussianbeauty:

17 May, 1910, Peterhof

My dear Mama! How are you feeling. I wanted to tell you that Olga would very much like to have her own room in Peterhof, because she and Tatiana have too many things and too little room. Mama at what age did you have your own room?Please tell me if it’s possible to…

twinkletwinklelittletsars:

Connections: The Family Tree

Tsar Nicholas II (Nicholas Alexandrovich Romanov) :

Born: May 18th, 1868; Alexander Palace, Tsarkoe Selo (St Petersburg), Russia

Died: July 17th, 1918; Impatiev House, Yekaterinburg, Russia

Buried: July 17th, 1998; St Peter and Paul Cathedral, St Petersburg, Russia

Mother: Princess Dagmar of Denmark, later Tsarina Maria Feodorovna

Father: Tsar Alexander III (Alexander Alexandrovich Romanov)

Married: November 26th, 1894 in the Grand Church at the Winter Palace, St Petersburg, Russia

Princess Alix of Hesse and by the Rhine:

Born: June 6th, 1872; Darmstadt, Hesse, German Empire

Died: July 17th, 1918; Impatiev House, Yekaterinburg, Russia

Buried: July 17th, 1998; St Peter and Paul Cathedral, St Petersburg, Russia

Mother: Princess Alice of the United Kingdom

Father: Grand Duke Ludwig IV of Hesse

Together they had five children:

Grand Duchess Olga Nikolaevna Romanova:

Born: November 15th, 1895; Alexander Palace, Tsarskoe Selo (St Petersburg), Russia

Died: July 17th, 1918; Impatiev House, Yekaterinburg, Russia

Buried: July 17th, 1998; St Peter and Paul Cathedral, St Petersburg, Russia

Grand Duchess Tatiana Nikolaevna Romanova:

Born: June 10th, 1897; Peterhof, St Petersburg, Russia

Died: July 17th, 1918; Impatiev House, Yekaterinburg, Russia

Buried: July 17th, 1998; St Peter and Paul Cathedral, St Petersburg, Russia

Grand Duchess Maria Nikolaevna Romanova:

Born: June 26th, 1899; Peterhof, St Petersburg, Russia

Died: July 17th, 1918; Impatiev House, Yekaterinburg, Russia

Buried: See note below

Grand Duchess Anastasia Nikolaevna Romanova:

Born: June 18th, 1901; Peterhof, St Petersburg, Russia

Died: July 17th, 1918; Impatiev House, Yekaterinburg, Russia

Buried: See note below

Tsarevich Alexei Nikolaevich Romanov:

Born: August 12th, 1904; Peterhof, St Petersburg, Russia

Died: July 17th, 1918; Impatiev House, Yekaterinburg, Russia

Buried: Alexei’s remains have not been reburied yet

**Note: I will discuss this more in detail later, but there were two different pits in which the family was originally buried after their murder. One was discovered in 1991 and the other in 2007. The bodies buried in the first pit were reburied in 1998, but the bodies buried in the second pit have not ben reburied. In the first pit were the bodies of Nicholas, Alexandra, Olga, Tatiana, and either Maria or Anastasia. In the second pit were the bodies of Alexei and either Anastasia or Maria. Either way, no one survived that night in the cellar.

Grand Duchess Maria in a car c. 1913.
